explanations: When mentioning two or more actions that take place in succession, they are listed in their order of occurence using using the て-form.
The tense of the sentence is determined by the tense form of the last verb in the sentences
examples: 1) 朝[あさ] ジョギングを して，シャワーを 浴[あ]びて，会社[かいしゃ]へ 行[い]きます。
1) In the mornings, I go jogging, take a shower and then go to work
2) 神戸[こうべ]へ 行[い]って，映画[えいが]を 見[み]て，お茶[ちゃ]を 飲[の]みました。
2) I went to Kobe, where I saw a movie and drank some tea

explanations: The て-form of a い-adj is formed by dropping the final い and attaching くて to it
[Note] ~て(で) cannot be used to connect two adjective sentences having the saem subject if they present two contrasting descriptions
[Note] In such cases, we use Adj1 が Adj2
examples: 1) ミラーさんは 若[わか]くて，元気[げんき]です。
1) Mr Miller is young and energetic
2) 昨日[きのう]は 天気[てんき]が よくて，暑[あつ]かったです。
2) It was fine and hot yesterday

explanations: The て-form of a な-adj is formed by appending で to it
[Note] ~て(で) cannot be used to connect two adjective sentences having the saem subject if they present two contrasting descriptions
[Note] In such cases, we use Adj1 が Adj2
examples: 1) ミラーさんは ハンサムで，親切[しんせつ]です。
1) Mr Miller is handsome and kind
2) 奈良[なら]は 静[しず]かで，きれいな 町[まち]です。
2) Nara is a quiet, beautiful city

explanations: The て-form of a Noun is formed by appending で to it
examples: 1) カリナさんは インドネシア人[じん]で，富士[ふじ]大学[だいがく]の 留学生[りゅうがくせい]です。
1) Karina is Indonesian, she's a student at Fuji University
2) カリナさんは 学生[がくせい]で，マリアさんは 主婦[しゅふ]です。
2) Karina is a student, and Maria is a housewife

explanations: In this sentence pattern, Verb2 expresses something done after Verb1
Verb1 is often a precondition of doing Verb2 or an action preparatory to doing it
The tense of the sentence is determined by the tense of the last verb in the sentence
examples: 1) お金[かね]を 入[い]れてから，ボタンを 押[お]して ください。
1) Put the money in, and then please press the button
2) もう 昼[ひる]ごはんを たべましたか。
2) Have you already had your lunch?
2) ... この 仕事[しごと]が 終[お]わってから，食[た]べます。
2) ... No, I'm going to have it when I've finished this job

topic: Noun1 は Noun2 が Adj
explanations: This expression indicates that the topic Noun1 has the characteristic Noun2 が Adj
examples: 1) 大阪[おおさか]は 食[た]べ物[もの]が おいしいです。
1) The food in Osaka is very good
2) ドイツの フランケンは ワインが 有名[ゆうめい]です。
2) Franken in Germany is famous for its wine
3) マリアさんは 髪が 長いです。
3) Maria has long hair

explanations: Verbs such as でます and おります, are used together with the particle を, indicating a starting point
examples: 1) 7時[じ]に うちを でます。
1) I leave home at seven
2) 梅田[うめだ]で 電車[でんしゃ]を 降[お]りました。
2) I got off the train at Umeda

explanations: どうやって is used when asking the way or how to do something
examples: 1) 大学[だいがく]まで どうやって 行[い]きますか。
1) How do you get to the University?
1) ... 京都駅[きょうとえき]から 16番[ばん]の バスに 乗[の]って，大学前[だいがくまえ]で 降[お]ります。
1) ... I take the number 16 bus from Kyoto Station and get off at Daigakumae

explanations: どれ is an interrogative used when asking someone to specify one item out of a list of three of more
どれ cannot modify a noun directly. When modifying a noun, どの is used
examples: 1) ミラーさんの 傘[かさ]は どれですか。
1) Which is Mr Miller's umbrella?
1) ... あの 青[あお]い 傘[かさ]です。
1) ... It's that blue one
2) サントスさんは どの 人[ひと]ですか。
2) Which is Mr Santos?
2) ... あの 背[せ]が 高[たか]くて，髪[かみ]が 黒[くろ]い 人[ひと]です。
2) ... That tall, black-haired man
